sentences.text: Let's kick this off with a question.
sentences.speaker: A

sentences.text: Do you need to add multiparty video calls to your website or app?
sentences.speaker: A

sentences.text: I'm talking about live video conference rooms that host 500 active participants, run in the browser, and work within your existing stack, and even support 1080p without devouring the bandwidth and CPU on your users devices.
sentences.speaker: A

sentences.text: Signal Wire offers the APIs, the SDKs and Edge networks around the world for building the real estate of real time voice and video communication apps with less than 50 milliseconds of latency.
sentences.speaker: A

sentences.text: Their core products use Webockets to deliver 300% lower latency than APIs built on rest, making them ideal for apps where every millisecond of responsiveness makes a difference.
sentences.speaker: A

sentences.text: Now you may wonder how they get 500 active participants in a browser based app.
sentences.speaker: A

sentences.text: Most current approaches use a limited but more economical approach called SFU, or selective forwarding units, which leaves the work of mixing and decoding all those video and audio streams of every participant to each user's device.
sentences.speaker: A

sentences.text: Browserbased apps built on SFU struggled to support more than 20 interactive participants, so Signal Wire mixes all the video and audio feeds on the server and distributes a single, unified stream back to every participant so you can build things like live streaming fitness Studios where instructors demonstrate every move from multiple angles, or even live shopping apps that highlight the charisma of the presenter and the charisma of the products they're pitching at the same time.
sentences.speaker: A

sentences.text: One thing that I'd love to add onto that is, well, two things.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: First of all, on the notion of price and related to which technology she should use.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: I think the question you constantly need to be asking is really never ask about one side of the equation.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: Never ask about features or price.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: You always want to be looking at a price performance ratio, and that performance shouldn't necessarily, in fact, usually should not be like metrics like gigabytes or throughput or anything like that.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: You should be looking at do you need what the product offers and what is it going to save you time on?
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: So like when Emily says if it's going to save you development time, that is gold, you always want to go like error on the side of saving development time.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: Developers are very expensive, we're very finicky.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: And anything that you develop, you also need to maintain.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: So one of the big benefits of cloud services is think of that price, not just in terms of development costs, but are you going to need to maintain it?
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: And on the flip side, do you need this thing at all?
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: Quite like Henneck was talking about, just not using cloud at all.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: And yet he successfully develops and deploys many services in production and they all seem fine.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: And so I think that there's often kind of this tool obsession where we look at features, features, features, and assume that features equals benefits.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: But features are only benefits to you if you need them.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: If you don't need them, they're additional cost.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: You have to learn stuff about every single one of those features.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: The time your developers spend learning the surface of the AWS API is a cost you have to think about.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: And so it's quite often just better to not use the cloud because it's cheaper to not figure it all out if you know how expensive it's going to be in your own infrastructure.

sentences.text: And like, how do you manage complexity at that scale?

sentences.text: How do you deal with the problems that come with that type of organization?
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: Even the shape of this debate has long bothered me, because the terms that we're using.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: Right.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: Do we want monoliths or microservices?
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: Asking that question is like saying, well, when we have a wheel, do we want it to be like an 18 Wheeler, like truck wheel, or do we want it to be like one of those wheels that comes on like a micro machine's car?
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: And the answer is, I don't know, what are you putting on the vehicle that this wheel is going to be attached to?
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: It really depends the question of how big do you want your service to be, which is, I think, a better question than do you want a micro service or a monolith?
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: It comes down to what is the surface area to volume ratio of your team?
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: It takes about twelve people to run a micro service.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: I would say like a dozen people per service is roughly what you should be thinking about.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: Plus, there's the fixed overhead of a micro service architecture where you need service discovery and tracing and logging and like a whole bunch of other stuff which you probably need in today's modern fancy cloud environment.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: If you're going to be able to leverage services like Honeycomb and Cloud Watch and just manage all your logs and not have to deal with that yourself, then you're talking about maybe a six person team that can just do infra.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: And if you are at a three person startup and thinking that sounds like a lot of people, you want a monolith, you want one piece of code you can maintain.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: Because the benefit of having something like a very fine grained micro service architecture is that you can say, we're going to have each team on its little piece, and we're going to move a lot of the complexity of orchestrating from code to configuration because our operations team can deal with the configuration and manage their process around testing configurations but if you're a small development team, you want code you can write unit tests for, you want code you can run and understand the way that you run and understand everything else.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: And if you push everything in DML files and Ini files and cloud APIs, what does your development environment look like anymore?

sentences.text: Specifically, one of the things that people often forget about the whole service architecture thing.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: And this comes down to, if you remember I said I was going to talk about choose your own language kind of thinking before.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: One of the things that people often choose micro service architecture for badly is this idea that they want to experiment with different programming languages because they want to use the right tool for the right job.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: And number one, just the cognitive overhead of jumping between Haskell and Ocamel and Python and rust on your back end is way higher than most people think.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: But even forgetting about the sort of human cognitive overhead, your service architecture, your service fabric needs to be logging and recording metrics and dealing with load balancers and dealing with data stores in a consistent way.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: And that task by itself is complex enough that you probably need a library, which means every supported language in your environment needs to have packages installed that are maintained by your infrastructure team and not by your application teams.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: And that means before you can even think about microservices, you have to be able to split your workflow into multiple different package repositories, different source control, different teams, different CI.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: You need to be able to do that first before you can reasonably split things across, like multiple actual services.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: That doesn't necessarily mean you need to not have a quote unquote monolith, because you can put a mono repo into that kind of multiple library workflow.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: And that's also fine.
sentences.speaker: C

sentences.text: But you do need to be able to have multiple work streams going that end up in the same service package.

sentences.text: The one flag I want to wave here is defense in depth, which is something that's very dear to my heart, which could be a bit more popular because every significant attack nowadays is a multi stage one.
sentences.speaker: D

sentences.text: It doesn't matter if it's like owning your Chrome or owning a server.
sentences.speaker: D

sentences.text: It's usually multiple stages, so you shouldn't make it as hard as possible to the attackers, even though they have entered your infrastructure at this point.
sentences.speaker: D
